Articles.Content:
Hi,

I am frequently getting into situation where I fail to slow down during reentry enough (~250 m/s) to deploy chute and I smash into the ground. Both: Jeb and Val finished this way, as well as few tourist. Is there any 100 % sure method for safe reentry? I am speaking about career mode with “90 science” tech-tree level unlocked, so I don’t have AIRBRAKES which are ultimate solution for this issue.

Second thing: how deep with Pe you go for aerocapture at Kerbin?

Coming back from the Mun or Minmus I'll usually aim for about a 35-40km Pe, this should slow me up enough to mean I land in 2 passes of the atmosphere without overheating a pod that doesn't have a heatshield fitted.

If you're hitting the ground without slowing down enough then either you're coming in too steep, or your craft isn't draggy enough.  One option might be to fit some smallish fins near to the CoM of your re-entry vehicles and then use SAS the get some angle off attack to increase drag.

For early game tourist missions I tend to use a stack of 3 Mk1 capsules with the middle one upside down, this is stable on re-rentry and providing I don't start off too steep has enough drag to slow down

Well, mostly, if you can maximise the amount of time you're going sideways, you'll be a lot less likely to smack headlong in the ground (since you're going sideways, not straight down). When you come back down, don't burn retrograde so your Pe goes into the planet - there's no need to do that, you'll be coming in very steep if you do. You might think it's safer to get through the 'fireball' of re-entry as quickly as possible but it's not - the heat effects are caused by you loosing kinetic energy - and the more kenetic energy you dissipate this way, the less your parachute needs to deal with when you want to deploy it.

If you put a point of your orbit within the atmosphere (even by just a few meters and for only a few seconds) what will happen is that the air resistance will (slightly) reduce your velocity - this will cause the altitude of the opposite side of your orbit to reduce. Eventually, with no other inputs, you will deorbit.  Though it will take many, many orbits to do this.  

Do ensure you'll land during the next orbit [or, at least, very soon], just put both your Pe and Ap a bit under 70km (say 60km).  You'll then continuously slow down.  But you will come in on a very shallow tradjectory, which will mean most of your kinetic energy from having orbital velocity will be gone when you get to the point when you're dropping straight down and are having to worry about how close the ground is - that way you'll be well, well within safe parachute speed at over 10km.

On 3/9/2016 at 3:24 AM, RizzoTheRat said:

If you're hitting the ground without slowing down enough then either you're coming in too steep, or your craft isn't draggy enough.

 

On 3/9/2016 at 6:12 AM, Wemb said:

Well, mostly, if you can maximise the amount of time you're going sideways, you'll be a lot less likely to smack headlong in the ground (since you're going sideways, not straight down).

In my experience, the steepness of reentry angle doesn't matter much when it comes to problems like "I'm hitting the ground while still going too fast to deploy parachutes."  As far as I can tell, what matters is mainly just the aerodynamics of the ship (i.e. its ballistic coefficient, how draggy it is relative to its mass).  So the thing to focus on is the shape, mass, and orientation of your reentering ship.

(Don't get me wrong, reentry angle is super important in terms of managing the "hot" part of reentry, and making sure you can slow down enough without burning up or exploding.  For that problem, yes it matters not to be too steep, and yes you want to be going mostly sideways for as long as possible in order to bleed off lots of speed before you get down into the barbecue zone.  But that's a different issue from faceplanting-at-higher-than-parachute-speed, which is what I'm talking about here.)

There are two main reasons why aero matters so much more than descent angle for this problem:

  • The air gets exponentially (read: "really quickly") thicker as your altitude drops, which drastically lowers your terminal velocity, especially when you get below 10 km or so.
  • Drag goes up fast with speed (it's the square of your velocity).  Craft that are falling much faster than terminal velocity slow down in a hurry.

The practical upshot of this is that by the time you hit the ground, you're going to be going around terminal velocity.  Maybe a little higher than it, but not much higher than it, no matter what your descent angle from space was.

Therefore, if you're having faceplanting problems, the thing to do is to manage the design of your reentering ship so that it has a reasonably low terminal velocity (i.e. significantly less than 200 m/s at sea level).

There are various ways to do that:

  • lower mass
  • bigger surface area ( = more drag)
  • play with your orientation to maximize drag and/or lift (body lift is your friend, as @Nich points out)

It's hard to give really specific advice without seeing a screenshot of the ship you're having problems with.  Could you post one?

Here are some examples of "good" and "bad" designs (from the standpoint of "faceplanting risk"):

Good:

  • A lone Mk1 command pod, without much attached to it beyond a parachute and maybe a heat shield.  It's naturally stable in the draggy (i.e. butt-first) direction, which helps for slowing down.  And it has very low mass hiding behind that 1.25m footprint.  These reenter like a dream.
  • A Mk1 pod, on top of an empty (or mostly-empty) 2-ton LFO tank, on top of a Terrier.  (Note, no heatshield needed-- this ship can reenter just fine without a heatshield from LKO, as long as you do so engine-first.  The Terrier is pretty heat-resistant.)  This design works because you can get great help from body lift.  Fly it engine-first all the way down.  As soon as you're finished with the hot part of reentry, use the torque from the command pod to angle it with the engine leading "high" and the command pod in the rear pointing down at about 30 degrees below retrograde.  Angling it like this will generate a lot of body lift.  So much, in fact, that you can actually stop your descent and climb a kilometer or two when you get down to 12km or so altitude!  Keeping that body-lift attitude will bleed your speed down so low that you're going a lot slower than 200 m/s by the time you get down to parachute-deployment altitude.
  • A long skinny "lawn-dart" ship with steerable fins on the back (like the AV-R8).  The control authority from the fins lets you angle-up and, again, make lots of body lift.
  • Pretty much any ship that has fins or wings near the middle, ideally slightly behind the CoM.  Not too far behind, or you'll lawn-dart it.  Not ahead, or you'll flip over backwards.  But with wings/fins just slightly behind the CoM, you can generate tons of lift to slow yourself.

Bad:

The classic example of a ship that has serious faceplanting problems is a Mk1 command pod sitting on top of something light and fluffy, for example a stack of two Science Jr. material bays.  The problem there is that it wants to fly pod-first because that's where the CoM is, and the command pod is too aerodynamic when it's flying pointy-end-first, and if your ship is too aerodynamically stable, you get locked in that nose-first attitude and can't do anything about it.  Result:  plow into terrain.

 

Anyway, my two cents.  If you can post a screenshot of the ship that's having problems, we can offer specific feedback about why it's having difficulty and how to fix it.
